pros: I have worked here for 15 years. I love the people I work with.
cons: Stressful occupation, under staffed, long shifts

review_title: Was my dream hospital; now it’s just whatever
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Escondido, CA
pros: Great co workers. Lab does all lab draws. CNAs will help with patient care. Doctors on the unit are usually fair, kind and professional.
cons: Pay is substantially less than other hospitals in San Diego and SD county. Cerner charting which is wack compared to EPIC. Usually no resource nurse, and management is always expecting more and shelling out more rules without ever paying more or offering support. Expectations are always rising and pay never is. Union contract is weak and management bickers with union at time of negotiation.

review_title: lowest RN pay in SD county
pros: working conditions are good, adequate resources, enough supplies and equipment, stays within CA staffing ratios
cons: pay, pay, pay; expensive healthcare benefits for employees, retirement better than Sharp or Scripps but not as good as Kaiser, UCSD, and VA, 6% money purchase pension plan and company match but only 1% for 2% employee contributions

review_title: 2 years felt like 5 years with all the overwork.
job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in Escondido, CA
pros: Easy work once you get a hang of inpatient pharmacy and master all of the multiple shifts. Coworkers can be nice, mainly made friends with my pharmacists and sometimes my fellow pharmacy technician colleagues. Be careful who you open up to about personal issues.
cons: Upper management could use some work. I do not trust their professionalism and the way they work. There is a lack of trust and a lack of reliability in pharmacy management and simply management as a whole as the hospital. Management victim blames and puts hard working technicians in stressful situations and puts them on paid leave to be investigated yet they allow predatory technicians to remain there with no consequences against them. Done with the company and looking into a restraining order against the creep that came after me when I first started.

pros: Great pay and great leaders
cons: There tends to be a lot of turnover with leaders

job_title: Clinical RN II in Escondido, CA
pros: My coworkers are what kept me there for so long, and the facility itself is nice.
cons: Poor Leadership, low pay, no lunches/breaks and chronically understaffed. Can have all the PTO but it never is approved. If you want to burn out quick- this is the place to go.

pros: benefits-generous pto accrual, umr health, vision,dental, 403B match, overall benefits are worth it if you are looking for health benefits as a priority Wages- pay rates range for support services 18-25 for full timers and per diem support staff 20–27, Nurse pay range starts around $45+, surgical techs and anesthesia techs $28+ Staff- staff is great teamplayers make work fun
cons: Travelers taking over hospital Low moral people leaving constantly for better pay Pay not competitive with other hospitals it’s below average, this hospital doesn’t have a budget like scripps or kaiser No growth unless you get certification Surg tech Anes tech RT Cath lab X-ray or RN CNA/ER tech pay sucks not worth it

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Escondido, CA

pros: There is a Starbucks inside the hospital

review_title: Love my co-workers & unit, but pay could be better

cons: Compensation is lowest in San Diego and definitely not competitive with the other hospitals in the area. Even through inflation and upper management & administration receiving very large bonuses, the hourly workers have not received an appropriate market increase raise and there seems to be no plans for that to happen.

pros: Great hospital, great new grad program
cons: The least paid in the county.

pros: My coworkers were fantastic. Great teamwork. Close group of people and always welcoming to newcomers. Manager on our floor was good though not always present. Same with Director.
cons: CEO and company overall don’t seem to care about employee retention or what’s best overall for patient care. Money seems to be a driving factor. After Covid times, let go of all our ED, Hospitalist, and ICU doctors to go with another group. Then let go of all our security guards to go with a cheaper group that wasn’t as experienced in hospital security. Every time the Union contract is up for negotiation it takes like 2 years to get it so any raises and changes are put on hold forever.

pros: Caring staff.  Very patient focused
cons:
Same old, same old. I believe that CEO Covert was well intentioned but I believe he spent a lot of unnecessary money on activity based leadership. First, University of Michigan business gurus $ spent on "culture change". Tremendous investment in Magnet status. Way over budget on new hospital. All of these things are "good ideas" but neither leadership nor staff was prepared to sustain theses changes. The Studer Group is another yet another undertaking. Major time and record keeping.  The leadership just keeps trying the flavor of the week.  Round, and get in touch with the staff --  collaborate with staff and identity three needed changes, communicate, communicate, and work toward THIS.  All this activity based leadership just confuses and in some cases can interfere with patient care.  Organizations task their department based leaders on "checking the boxes" on their progress reports regarding these activities and 
busyness other than leading. It is a tough job and the reality is there are only so many hours in a day
I am encouraged by the new CEO, she has a very good background.

job_title: Reimbursement Specialist in San Marcos, CA
pros: They do offer flexible hours
cons: The management is horrible and the new change in health insurance is disappointing

pros: I love my fellow RN's and CNA's. I wouldn't be able to endure if it weren't! For them.
cons: Lack of resources or wasteful use of them. Managements  inability to recognize when a technology or design implemented to help work flow does not work.

job_title: Medical Technologist in San Diego, CA
pros: Great job to work at I emjoyed
cons: Not so much room for growth

pros: No pros for this company
cons: Worst place of employment ever. All staff are a dime a dozen.

pros: Decent hourly pay and benefits. Lots of hours available to work.
cons:
There is a toxic culture among therapists at the Poway location. It feels like middle school where certain cliques think they are better than others and give others a hard time,  such as telling you how to do your job and talking behind your back. Even after reporting these bullies to HR and manager, no change occurred. New grads are not welcomed by all and are constantly being judged as if perfection was required immediately. You may be blamed for something which was actually someone else's mistake and they reported you instead to cover themselves. Pro tip: rehab aide must be regularly bribed before she will consider assisting you.

On another note, although productivity level seems lower than other SNFs, everyone works through their lunch and after they clock out to complete documentation on a redundant system (CERNER). Wheelchairs and parts are mismatched and dangerous to both therapist and patient. Charge nurses who don't care and won't crack a smile. 

Steer clear, physical and occupational therapists!

pros: Small hospital with many great coworkers, great patient population, some amazing physicans.
cons: Staffing is often messed up. Chief of surgery is a nightmare for nursing to work with. Management lacks leadership and communication skills . Some nurses display unprofessional behavior on a regular basis since it is a small comfortable place to work. There is never enough equipment to safely do your job. Technology is old and doesn't often work. Punitive punishment is often doled out for small things and puts self reporting and safe patient care at risk. Education is lacking and not cutting edge.

review_title: Don't look for management support or appreciation.
job_title: Licensed Psychiatric Clinician in Poway, CA
pros: There used to be pros a long time ago, but that stopped and it went 180 in a negative direction.  Can't identify one pro currently.
cons: Where would I start?  Don't expect management to step up to stop discrimination, abuse, slander.  Regardless of the truth, you will be blamed and penalized.  Expectations are different for employees in the same department, depending on whether you are perceived as the "Golden Child" of the moment.  The working conditions are brutal, the environment is unhealthy physically and mentally  There is a huge deficit of available work space and equipment, making it difficult, if not impossible, to do your work.

pros: My work at Palomar Health started many years ago.  Being part of the leadership of an organization that has gone through change after change after change can be difficult on our colleagues and staff.   We stay and support the new and changing direction which is difficult with new leadership and now a new board.  Progress has been made but at what cost?  Layoffs of leadership, and now staff, to course correct the financial cliff, has been difficult for everyone and is plagued with issues.  We will continue to support our colleagues and staff in hopes of returning Palomar to what it was during our better years!  As leaders, we must refocus.
cons: Palomar is a wonderful place to be when thinking about the care we provide and challenging when thinking about the business outlook especially with the lack of strong executive and financial leadership.

job_title: Clinical RN II in Escondido, CA
pros: Pay is good, union helps employees, very good HMO health plan through Sharp. Very good orientation for employees
cons: We are understaffed most of the time and our workload keeps increasing. The chairs and workstations we chart at are very uncomfortable and many are broken

pros: There is a great amount of flexibility and the management is heavily invested in its staff. It's great atmosphere to work in.
cons: Of all the little frustrations that accompany the position there really is little that I could really complain about that wouldn't occur elsewhere. When it comes down to it, there are a few places that pay better, but I hear that we're treated far better. I could move for better pay, but I suspect I'd regret leaving.

job_title: Social Worker Per Diem in Escondido, CA
pros: Social workers have assistants and UR nurses to assist them with discharge planning. Social workers work closely with doctors and nurses to achieve hospital goals and remain in budget. Social workers are tight knit.
cons: Although social workers are close, everyone talks badly behind everyone's back when someone leaves the room. Upper management does not seem to care about their staff, including their staff needs and patient needs. The social work department also has a bad reputation. Low values as the main focus is to discharge patients rather than focus on patient's needs.

pros: easy patients, lunch breaks
cons: terrible communication, willing to throw away good nurses over small issues, don't waste your time with this employer

pros: This health system has made a lot of positive changes since the new hospital opened in 2012.  Lately new leaders and a new CEO have brought new ideas, and a lot of fresh energy.  I have seen plenty of people get promoted to leadership positions when it was deserved.
cons: For those that don't live in North County San Diego, it can be a challenge to get there.  Many people commute from Riverside County, or the beach towns.

review_title: The only hospital employer I've ever had
pros: A nearly brand new hospital, so the equipment works and the facility is well maintained. Its a beautiful place to work.
cons: Since moving into the new hospital staff feel more anonomous, almost as if we are part of the equipment.  Patient care staff are spread out and isolated with no central nursing stations, so professional comraderie and cohesiveness have suffered.

pros: There is constant change, which I like. They are growing & looking towards the future. CEO seems to actually care about the hospital & its future & the culture is trying to change for the better.
cons: No name recognition in the community. Most executives are out of touch with what is going on & play obvious favorites (which is good if you are one of the favorites!). Opinions are asked of the "regular" workers, but it feels like they aren't listened to.

review_title: Change has been good for Palomar
pros:
New management team is doing some things.  

I’ve been here for many years and it’s the first time that layoffs didn’t impact the people who do the real work, which was a pleasant surprise.
cons: Many people who’ve been here for a long time who are just collecting a paycheck.  Prior CEO was clueless and was invisible to the front line staff.

pros: Love the supportive fellow nursing staff.  They encourage education and there are always growth opportunities for those who want it.
cons: Like anywhere dealing with Dr attitudes of arrogance can be difficult to handle. There needs to be better education for these docs on how respectful deal with conflict that may arise.

review_title: Don't speak up or try to improve the system in any way-or else!
pros: job with a steady income but other than that and he nearly perfect climate of the San Diego area, I can't think of a single thing.
cons: They try to save money in every aspect which obviously will affect patient care-and satisfaction or lack there of. But if patient satisfaction scores are below 90% the staff don't get a raise. The CEO on the other hand gets a huge bonus for saving the organization money!

review_title: I am always happy to go to work!
pros: The patient is our number one priority in the O.R. and the my coworkers make everyday worth while.
cons: I believe that some of the supervising staff is a little excessive and that some are lacking general O.R. knowledge to be in a supervisor position.

review_title: Volunteer Front Desk Palomar Medical Center
pros: Helping people by directing them to the patients hospital room,  Explaining to visitors the rules and policies visitors must following when visiting patients.
cons: Majority of visitors are Hispanic and approx. 95% of the volunteers are only English speaking.  There needs to be an interpreter on duty  from 8am until 8pm while volunteers are working the front desk.

job_title: Physical Therapist in San Diego, CA
pros: Palomar has a great orientation process, a lot of staff support and opportunities for continuing education. Palomar is a very team oriented place to work.
cons: Scheduling can be rigid and it is difficult to have time off. Management is not flexible with regards to the schedule. This is somewhat understandable, as there it is a large staff with a lot of patients to treat.

pros:
Work from home once per week option. 
Friendly team/staff.
Good entry level Heathcare IT Ops job.
cons:
Work not fairly distributed amongst team members. Long time Palomar workers tend to hoard most of the challenging projects. 
Poor compensation for new hires in order to protect the inflated salaries of long time workers. 
Afraid of change. 
Self insured health insurance plan. Keeps company costs low, but detritimental to those located outside of Kansas City

review_title: Overall has been a great company to work for as my first health care employer!
pros: Before being hired full time, I spent about 18 months as a student volunteer.  The staff has always been very helpful and receptive towards me.  The training was thorough and educational.  Palomar Health has a great atmosphere!
cons: At this point I do not see anything negative about this employer.  (Most employers are experiencing challenges in todays economy.  Palomar is no different..)

review_title: Cooking for patients feels like a good contribution to the community.
pros: Palomar Health pays their employees well. Benefits are some of the best out there. There are opportunities to move up and transfer to different departments.
cons: Full Time positions are very hard to achieve. There is a union so the senior people get priority of opportunities. Parking is not convenient for employees.

pros: Great benefits and work atmosphere. Employees are important and this healthcare system does not put up with verbal abuse from doctors or anyone else.
cons: Some supervisors show favoritism. This happens at any facility out there, but I found very few cons during the years I worked here.

pros: Parking, ER staff and leaders are great, beautiful Escondido hospital, many great physicians who are committed, nursing staff willing to help each other out
cons: Lack of job security unless you are covered by the union, constant turnover in leadership so no focus, HR policies are poorly and inconsistently implemented. Culture rewards mediocre management who keep the status quo, so if you are at all innovative go to Sharp or Scripps. No communication on where the company is headed.

review_title: Pretty on the outside, Ugly on the inside.
job_title: Registered Nurse III in Escondido, CA
pros: Facility is beautiful and still looks new. Not much else to say that’s positive.
cons: No support from management for staff. The environment and culture towards staff is very punitive, and you are treated as if you’re lucky to work there, not as a valued professional. I didn’t realize how toxic the place is until I was employed at a facility that values its people again.

pros: Palomar is an excellent company to work for. I was a new grad when I started and they put me through all the necessary training to be a successful L&D nurse.
cons: For me, it was the drive and working night shift. All the employees have worked there for many years and it was difficult for me to be transferred to day shift.

pros: great training for new grads, good variety of diagnoses, great pay/benefits
cons: ridiculous productivity expectations  tied to yearly raises, high school like atmosphere, toxic work environment, unethical practices/fraud

pros: Management treats staff fairly. Staff are friendly once they get to know you. Health System striving to be competitive in todays fought health care market.
cons: Few opportunities to advance. There does not seem to be any interest in developing current staff into future leaders.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Escondido, CA
pros: Fairly strong union, great benefits, lots of opportunities for mobility and training if you seek it, basically unlimited overtime if you want.
cons: Slightly lower pay than other San Diego county hospitals, lots of useless mandatory trainings, inefficient patient flow processes.  Upper management doesn’t even pretend to care about patient care, only talk about numbers and productivity.

pros: Beautiful facility and grounds.  Potential to serve communities in need who would otherwise have to travel many miles for care.
cons: Lack of vision and ability to execute the basics.  Debt burden draining the life out of operations.  Quality issues abound.  Might be best to wait for a new leadership team before jumping in here.

pros: Very flexible with a great clinical team. Wonderful clinical experience with an opportunity to work with multiple disciplines. Great way to work with community
cons: High stress and could use more staff to assist with the assigned duties.  Could also be more competitive with wages considering many staff leave for higher paying jobs at other hospitals.

pros: always new challenges to boost your knowledge and skill, great working hours, weekends off better than average pay scale
cons: long hours standing, sometimes difficult to work for/under doctor supervision and orders, complex case load with increased pressure to perform

pros:
Benefits
benefits
benefits
This is all I can think of

review_title: It's a great place to work!
pros: Everyone is so nice there. Even though I was there for my externship I was treated like one of the Phlebotomists.
cons: Parking is so far away for employees. That's about the only horrible con I have to say about it. The cafeteria is a bit pricey.

pros: Benefits and salary were good-especially if you have been there a while
cons: The HR department is a mess. The whole system-if you aren't on supervisor/director good side, you will be pushed out at some point.

pros: Excellent mentorship, excellent coworkers, very much a family environment
cons: Little flexibility with scheduling. It was made very clear that if you weren’t happy you could leave because there were plenty of new grads they could pay less that would happily take your spot

pros: Nice building that is all.

Terrible H.R. Dept.  They are rude and just don't care at all.  
There are dept. "leads" in some areas who are not competent at all, and yet they remain "in charge," year after year.  So if you are part of the old timer group you are safe.  The previous CEO got bonuses for layoffs!  Shocking way to run a hospital.

cons: The health care district served by Palomar Health faces stiff competition from hospitals.  This can sometimes mean that if census is down, hours get cut.

pros: Love my job. Good environment,  great patients. Good pay!
